border between Turkey and northern Syria
what's happening where you are Martin
and around the 200k area around you as
well well a short while ago we saw
Turkish shelling into the Syrian town
behind me it's about a kilometer away
and that's been the real focus of

overnight there was heavy clashes
between Turkish special forces and the
Kurdish dominated Syrian ballot and
democratic forces in that town it looks
like most of it is now under Turkish
control and that's something that they
want to replicate along the border we
also know in one key town there's also

70 kilometers away from where I'm
standing
so this operation this incursion is
ongoing and we know that Turkish forces
are pushing in to a string of towns and
villages along this border throughout

civilians in this area a huge amount of
worry and panic are you hearing about
any casualties
we're not hearing about a huge number of
casualties the latest figures I have are
at least seven civilians have been
killed that's from Kurdish forces and we
haven't been able to verify that what is
clear is there's a great deal of panic
across the border the time behind me is
incredibly quiet and I think that's a
situation replicated along this border
because civilians are not going to sit
and wait they're gonna take their
opportunity to flee southwards it's a
very uncertain future one man I spoke to
in a town said that hundreds of people
were simply sleeping in orchards
overnight and let's not forget this is a
country Syria is a country where half
the population has already been forced
from their homes
no humanitarian agencies are warning of
potentially a new crisis but thanks so

patients they're right on the border
between northern Syria and Turkey well
as the Turkish offensive unfolds we are
watching to see what it will mean for
thousands of Islamic state fighters
being kept in Syrian prisons close to

it is detaining more than 12,000 men
suspected of being IIST members and
seven prisons at least 4,000 of those

now the SDF has said its fighters will

it's unclear whether they will continue

meanwhile as the US has been moving some

seen here on the left and Alexander Cote
on the right accused of being part of an

in Syria well let's bring in our
security correspondent Gordon Carrera
first out to those is prisoners how many
of them are there how are they guarded
and what's the threat there Gordon well
there's a mix because you've got some
very large prisons which have a number
of fighters and a lot of those fighters
are from Iraq and Syria and then you
have smaller situations where you have
what are called high-value detainees
which are some of the
more serious foreign fighters that the
that other countries have been worried
about what we've seen then is is the
u.s. appearing to act on some
contingency plans it had to go after

it thinks are particularly significant
and try and move them and so as well as

el-sheikh and Cote appears there was a

a bit unclear but with the wider issue
of the other thousands of prisoners I
think that is where there is a lot of

those guarding have already struggled to
sometimes keep order in them and the
fear is that if those Kurdish guards are

if something happens there you could

foreign fighters go back to Europe what

there are a lot of worries from

where this might end up and for the

you know it's up to the Kurds to

because of the withdrawal so the notice
is not there no that's right and you can
you can see why if you're the Kurdish
